III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4109 Program statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(b) The services provided to residents and parents directly by
the institution and the services provided by outside resources.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A has not received weekly individual therapy since 7/12/22.
Investigation I notified the Complainant, who is also DHHS Supervisor, that
DCWL was assigned this complaint. Complainant indicated she
received the allegation second-hand from one of Youth A’s
workers. I notified the Foster Care and Juvenile Justice workers
of the investigation assignment and neither expressed additional
concerns.
I notified Chief Administrator and Director of the allegation.
I reviewed Youth A’s clinical case notes from 7/12/22 – 3/8/23
authored by Therapist and entered in MISACWIS. Documentation
indicates Youth A was seen for individual therapy 36 times in 36
weeks. During weeks 9/26/22 and 1/31/23, Therapist was out of
the office but held double sessions the following week. It should
be noted that Complainant, Foster Care and Juvenile Justice
worker all presumably have access to the clinical case notes in
MISACWIS.
I interviewed Youth A on 3/16/23. He is a MDHHS dual ward who
has resided at the facility since 7/12/22. Asked about the
2

allegation, Youth A denied telling anyone he is not receiving
weekly individual therapy. Rather, he corrected, “I’m not getting
the right (type of) therapy.” After some discussion, it became
evident that Youth A dislikes treatment work that focuses on his
current negative behaviors. Conversely, he feels treatment is
appropriate when it focuses on his past and the specific charge(s)
that brought him to Lincoln Center. Further, Youth A claimed his
judge ordered the type of therapy the youth values and “did not”
order the type he finds useless. Specifically, Youth A does not
see the value of working on current behaviors or how his present
relates to his past. Essentially, he feels that addressing his
current behaviors prolongs his ability to complete the program and
get released.
I interviewed Youth B’s Therapist. She said she has regular
contact with Youth B’s Foster Care and Juvenile Justice Workers
and neither expressed concerns that she is not doing the
appropriate amount or type of therapy. I recommended Therapist
reach out to the workers and provide an extensive explanation of
the therapy model as it is one that is widely used by clinicians who
work with juvenile justice youth.
Analysis Lincoln Center’s program statement and contract indicates each
youth in residential treatment receives weekly individual therapy
by a Clinical Case Manager (Therapist). Youth A is receiving the
type and amount of individual therapy identified in the program
statement.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
